entry.title: Effective Testing - Show What's Important, Hide the Rest
entry.content:
What we include in a test is as important as what we leave out. Having the right amount of information helps us understand what the test is doing at a glance.

Let’s say we need to check our Restaurants are behaving correctly. We want to validate two things:

  1. That a restaurants can only cook a Recipe if they have all the necessary ingredients.
  2. That vegan restaurants do not serve non-vegan food

{% img center /images/posts/2020-09-07/restaurantTestsBefore.png 700 â€˜Repetitive testsâ€™ %}

This works fine, but writing a new Recipe for every single test gets repetitive pretty fast. More importantly, most lines of the test are spent creating the Recipe object. By having to spell out every single property, we lose track of whatâ€™s important for each specific test.

Luckily, we can use Kotlin default arguments to make the tests better. We could introduce default values directly on the Recipe class, but that would mean weâ€™d have to pick sensible defaults for Recipes in production. We probably donâ€™t want to allow for this flexibility, as we want to force users to specify those properties for each recipe defined. Instead, we will write a helper function with default arguments to handle the Recipe creation. Weâ€™ll make it private so that itâ€™s only accessible in the test class.

{% img center /images/posts/2020-09-07/helperFunction.png 700 â€˜Helper functionâ€™ %}

Now we can re-write our tests to make use of the helper function:

{% img center /images/posts/2020-09-07/restaurantTestsAfter.png 700 â€˜Improved testsâ€™ %}

On each test, we only specify the property that the test cares about and leave out all the other ones. This way, somebody glancing at the test can immediately identify what weâ€™re checking, and itâ€™s not distracted by the details on how to create a Recipe object.

Note that this is a simplified example. In real life, the object being created could have multiple nested objects and require many steps to be initialized. All that code would be hidden in our helper function instead of bloating every test.

We could have written the test for vegan recipes without specifying any property, and it would still pass.

{% img center /images/posts/2020-09-07/notExplicit.png 700 â€˜Not explicit enough testsâ€™ %}

By default isVegan is true, so we’re not required to define it. However, we opted for explicitly specifying it in the test, just so that somebody reading the test would know that the value of isVegan is important for this test. As an extra benefit, the test will not break if, in the future, somebody decides to change the default value for isVegan.

entry.title: Effective Testing - Reducing Non-determinism to Avoid Flaky Tests
entry.content:
Flaky tests are those that randomly fail for no apparent reason. If you have a flaky test, you might re-run it, over and over, until it succeeds. If you have a couple of them, the chances of all passing at the same time are slim, so maybe you ignore the failures. You know, just this one timeâ€¦ Soon enough, youâ€™re not paying attention to failures on this test suite. Congratulations! Your tests are now worthless.

Prefer smaller tests

Non-determinism is often introduced as a consequence of relying on external services. For example, letâ€™s say our test needs to read data from a database, the test might fail if the database is down, or the data is not present, or has changed.

You’ve probably seen the Test Pyramid before. Tests are classified by scope, and the recommendation is to favor tests with reduced scopes (i.e. Unit Tests).

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-31/TestingPyramid.jpg 700 â€˜Using data classes for assertionsâ€™ %}

At Google they came up with a new dimension: Test Size1. Tests are grouped in categories based on the resources a test needs to run (memory, processes, time, etc.).

  • X-Small tests are limited to a single thread or coroutine. They are not allowed to sleep, do I/O operations, or make network calls.
  • Small tests run on a single process. All other X-Small restrictions still apply.
  • Medium tests are confined to a single machine. Canâ€™t make network calls to anywhere other than localhost.
  • Large tests can span multiple machines. They’re allowed to do everything.

Scope and Size are related, but independent. You could have an end-to-end test of a CLI tool that runs in a single process.

How does this tie back to our crusade against flaky tests? Simple, the smaller the test, the more deterministic itâ€™ll be. As a bonus perk, they also tend to be faster.

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-31/TestSizes.jpg 700 â€˜Test sizesâ€™ %}

Google went the extra mile and built infrastructure to enforce these constraints. For example, a test marked as Small would fail if it tried to do I/O.

How to make your test small

Some ways you can reduce the size of your test:

  1. Use Test Doubles to avoid making calls to external services.
  2. Use an in-memory Database.
  3. Use an in-memory filesystem.
  4. Design your classes so that test can provide a custom time source instead of relying on the system clock.
  5. Use kotlinx-coroutines-test to virtually advance time without having to make your test wait.
  6. Use Testcontainers to turn a Large test into a Medium one.

The trade-off

The downside of artificially isolating your tests is that they lose Fidelity. Meaning, what you end up testing is further away from what will run in production. Iâ€™ve been bitten by this in the past.

The trick is to have a test distribution similar to the one proposed by the Test Pyramid. We should have lots of Small and X-Small tests, some Medium tests, and only a few Large tests.

This post is part of the Effective Testing Series.

{% img right-fill /images/signatures/signature2.png 200 â€˜My signatureâ€™ %}

  1. The name is unfortunate as itâ€™s not immediately obvious what Size refers to.↩

entry.title: Effective Testing - Expressive Assertions
entry.content:
Using expressive assertions can help us figure out why a test fails without having to go through the code.

Let’s start with an example. Here’s a test making sure our recipe has tomatoes ğŸ…

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-19/badAssertion.png 700 â€˜A test with a non-descriptive assertionâ€™ %}

At first glance, everything looks ok. The test passes, it is easy to read, and it follows the â€Given - When - Thenâ€ structure.

Some months go by, and one day our test starts failing.

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-19/badAssertionOutput.png 700 â€˜The output of a test with a non-descriptive assertionâ€™ %}

At this point, we’ve probably forgotten everything about the recipe, and weâ€™re not sure whatâ€™s causing the failure. The test name is not helping us much either.

To avoid this situation, we can include a message that will be displayed whenever the assertion fails.

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-19/withMessage.png 700 â€˜Assertion with explicit messageâ€™ %}

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-19/withMessageOutput.png 700 â€˜Output of a test with an assertion with explicit messageâ€™ %}

Now the failure is obvious. There is no ğŸ… on the recipe. We can immediately tell whatâ€™s wrong without even looking at the test code. But we can do betterâ€¦

Assertion libraries

Let’s face it, writing this kind of detailed message for every assertion would be a pain in the ass. Fortunately, we donâ€™t have to. Instead, we can use an expressive assertion library to do the heavy lifting for us. This is how our code would look like using Strikt:

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-19/strikt.png 700 â€˜Example using Striktâ€™ %}

We’re using Kotlin infix notation to make the code more readable. This a stylistic decision, you donâ€™t have to use it if you donâ€™t like it.

You might notice we’re calling the contains method on the assertion itself. This is possible because Strikt can tell that the type weâ€™re asserting on, is a String, and thus, it can provide methods explicitly tailored to Strings. This is what the error message would look like in this case:

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-19/outputStrikt.png 700 â€˜Output of the basic Strikt exampleâ€™ %}

Almost the same information we got from writing our own message, but without the boilerplate.

Assertion libraries are like swiss army knives; they provide all kinds of assertions for different types of objects. I suggest learning a few of the core ones through the documentation, and then letting the IDE guide you with auto-suggestions to discover new ones.

Here are some more examples of type-specific assertions:

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-19/collectionAssertion.png 700 â€˜Collection specific assertionsâ€™ %}

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-19/assertingExceptions.png 700 â€˜Asserting exceptionsâ€™ %}

Asserting on objects

When validating properties on objects, you might be tempted to write something like this:

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-19/badObjectAssertions.png 700 â€˜Manually asserting properties on objectâ€™ %}

You can probably tell why this is bad. By the time we see the failure, we no longer have context on what property weâ€™re asserting.

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-19/objectAssertionOutput.png 700 â€˜Using data classes for assertionsâ€™ %}

Was it checking the title, the author, or something else?

Instead, you can take advantage of the fact that Data Classes automatically get equals and toString implementations. So we can use an assertEquals and get a nice looking message showing us both instances.

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-19/dataClasses.png 700 â€˜Using data classes for assertionsâ€™ %}

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-19/dataClassesOutput.png 700 â€˜Using data classes test outputâ€™ %}

If we don’t care about comparing all properties we can use Strikt to assert only specific fields:

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-19/traversingObjects.png 700 â€˜Using Strikt to traverse objects on assertionsâ€™ %}

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-19/traversingObjectsOutput.png 700 â€˜Strikt object traversal test outputâ€™ %}

The block assertion style means that even though the title assertion failed Strikt will still check for page count and itâ€™ll provide output for all the assertions in the block.

entry.title: Effective Testing - Test Structure
entry.content:
One way to make sure your tests are readable is to have them all adhere to the same structure.

By far, the most common structure is “Given - When - Thenâ€ (aka â€œArrange, Act, Assertâ€). It goes like this:

  1. On Given: We create the objects and set up the needed state.
  2. On When: We perform the action we want to test.
  3. On Then: We validate the state changed as expected.

For example:

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-10/exampleJunit.png 700 â€˜Example of the proposed structure using JUnitâ€™ %}

The comments explaining each section are optional, and can be omitted on trivial scenarios like the one shown here.

Note how we use whitespace to clearly separate each section. Anybody familiar with the structure will be able to easily identify each section at a glance.

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-10/testSections.jpg 700 â€˜Colored sections on testâ€™ %}

Some testing libraries like Kotest support a style that already includes the Given, When and Then keywords, making the structure explicit.

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-10/exampleKotest.png 700 â€˜Example of the proposed structure using Kotestâ€™ %}

entry.title: Effective Testing - Use Descriptive Test Names
entry.content:
Picking good test names can help us identify what’s wrong with our code when something fails.

It’s Friday afternoon. You finally finished that long refactor youâ€™ve been working on for the whole week. Everything is looking good. Except you run the tests and see one failure.

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-05/BadNames.png â€˜Test output with bad test namesâ€™ %}

ğŸ¤”

Unfortunately, you can’t really tell what’s broken from looking at that output. Youâ€™ll have to browse the test code to identify the failure.

But what if the output looked more like this:

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-05/GoodNames.png â€˜Test output with good test namesâ€™ %}

Now the issue is obvious. You can immediately tell which part of the code is not working and what the output should be.

Test names are the first (and often only) piece of information we see about a test. Using a descriptive test name can help us identify whatâ€™s broken at a glance. Furthermore, it helps us keep the test focused on validating one specific behavior, discouraging us from inflating the test with other unrelated assertions.

How

Instead of just using the name of the method being tested, try focusing on the behavior you want to validate. Describe the state of the system, the action performed, and the expected output. More often than not, youâ€™ll end up with a huge name, something you probably wouldnâ€™t use on production code, but thatâ€™s ok.

If you’re using Kotlin, you can use backticks to have whitespaces in your function name. If youâ€™re working with JUnit you can leverage the @DisplayName annotation for prettier names. You can even get emojis in there:

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-05/WithEmojis.png â€˜Test output with emojisâ€™ %}

You can also write a custom name generator using @DisplayNameGeneration as shown here.

Some testing libraries like Kotest, also support nesting tests:

{% img center /images/posts/2020-07-05/NestedNames.png â€˜Test output with emojisâ€™ %}

You can read more about test naming in Chapter 12 of Software Engineering at Google.

This post is part of the Effective Testing Series.
